issue.title: several urdf models appear to be missing head link

content.raw:
I think it might be the case that these urdf files are dead code and should be removed. From what I can tell the preferred way to use the atlas urdf is via the xacro file as such:

 
```
#!xml

<param name="robot_description" command="$(find xacro)/xacro.py '$(find atlas_description)/robots/atlas.urdf.xacro'"/>
```

Are the static files still needed? If so should they simply be regenerated via xacro?
content.html:
I think it might be the case that these urdf files are dead code and should be removed. From what I can tell the preferred way to use the atlas urdf is via the xacro file as such:

<param name="robot_description" command="$(find xacro)/xacro.py '$(find atlas_description)/robots/atlas.urdf.xacro'"/>

Are the static files still needed? If so should they simply be regenerated via xacro?

issue.title: several urdf models appear to be missing head link

content.raw:
the files in [`atlas_description/urdf`](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/fb860e62722c449868fa395e3eece367b3ac0b4a/atlas_description/urdf/?at=default) are used by files in [`atlas_description/robots`](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/fb860e62722c449868fa395e3eece367b3ac0b4a/atlas_description/robots/?at=default) to generate full robot models.  So, yes, these urdf files are needed.  And the way to use these urdf component files is to invoke [xacro](http://ros.org/wiki/xacro), e.g., similar to your launch script reference, commandline usage below:
~~~
rosrun xacro xacro.py `rospack find atlas_description`/robots/atlas.urdf.xacro
~~~

Referencing pull request #408, we now generate full models and install them into the install targets  at compile time (see issue #373 for more discussions).

Note, the `head` links are included when full robot configuration is used.  For example, take a look at [`atlas.urdf.xacro`](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/fb860e62722c449868fa395e3eece367b3ac0b4a/atlas_description/robots/atlas.urdf.xacro?at=default), it simply refers to different parts of the robot:
~~~
<robot xmlns:xacro="http://www.ros.org/wiki/xacro" name="atlas" >
  <xacro:include filename="$(find atlas_description)/urdf/atlas_simple_shapes.urdf" />
  <xacro:include filename="$(find atlas_description)/urdf/atlas.gazebo" />
  <xacro:include filename="$(find atlas_description)/urdf/atlas.transmission" />
  <xacro:include filename="$(find multisense_sl_description)/urdf/multisense_sl.urdf" />
</robot>
~~~
where the line
~~~
  <xacro:include filename="$(find multisense_sl_description)/urdf/multisense_sl.urdf" />
~~~
pulls in the head link through [`multisense_sl.urdf`](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/fb860e62722c449868fa395e3eece367b3ac0b4a/multisense_sl_description/urdf/multisense_sl.urdf?at=default).
content.html:
the files in atlas_description/urdf are used by files in atlas_description/robots to generate full robot models. So, yes, these urdf files are needed. And the way to use these urdf component files is to invoke xacro, e.g., similar to your launch script reference, commandline usage below:

rosrun xacro xacro.py `rospack find atlas_description`/robots/atlas.urdf.xacro

Referencing pull request #408, we now generate full models and install them into the install targets at compile time (see issue #373 for more discussions).

Note, the head links are included when full robot configuration is used. For example, take a look at atlas.urdf.xacro, it simply refers to different parts of the robot:

<robot xmlns:xacro="http://www.ros.org/wiki/xacro" name="atlas" >
  <xacro:include filename="$(find atlas_description)/urdf/atlas_simple_shapes.urdf" />
  <xacro:include filename="$(find atlas_description)/urdf/atlas.gazebo" />
  <xacro:include filename="$(find atlas_description)/urdf/atlas.transmission" />
  <xacro:include filename="$(find multisense_sl_description)/urdf/multisense_sl.urdf" />
</robot>

where the line

  <xacro:include filename="$(find multisense_sl_description)/urdf/multisense_sl.urdf" />

pulls in the head link through multisense_sl.urdf.

issue.title: several urdf models appear to be missing head link

content.raw:
Thanks for the clarification. I was resurrecting some code from 9 months ago that was using it in an old way and misunderstood.

Sorry for the noise.

issue.title: several urdf models appear to be missing head link

content.raw:
Had a thought: 

I'm not sure if it's worth the bother, but since those files are incomplete urdfs, perhaps they should take a suffix to indicate their role following the example of "atlas.gazebo" for instance. 

In this scheme "atlas.urdf" would be renamed "atlas.urdf.part" or something similar.


I have an untested branch that does this for illustration:
```
#!bash

find ./ -name "*.xacro" | xargs grep "urdf/\w*\.urdf[^.\w]" * -r --color
find ./ -name "*.xacro" | xargs -n1 sed -i "s:\(urdf/\w*\.urdf\)\([^.\w]\):\1.part\2:g"
find ./ | grep "urdf/.*.urdf$" | while read item; do hg mv $item ${item}.part; done
```

https://bitbucket.org/andy_somerville/drcsim/commits/43114a087faf4897a9445a010a04f616196f26ff
content.html:
Had a thought:

I'm not sure if it's worth the bother, but since those files are incomplete urdfs, perhaps they should take a suffix to indicate their role following the example of "atlas.gazebo" for instance.

In this scheme "atlas.urdf" would be renamed "atlas.urdf.part" or something similar.

I have an untested branch that does this for illustration:

find ./ -name "*.xacro" | xargs grep "urdf/\w*\.urdf[^.\w]" * -r --color
find ./ -name "*.xacro" | xargs -n1 sed -i "s:\(urdf/\w*\.urdf\)\([^.\w]\):\1.part\2:g"
find ./ | grep "urdf/.*.urdf$" | while read item; do hg mv $item ${item}.part; done

https://bitbucket.org/andy_somerville/drcsim/commits/43114a087faf4897a9445a010a04f616196f26ff

issue.title: several urdf models appear to be missing head link
several urdf models appear to be missing head link

content.raw:
@andy_somerville
I like your suggestion, but it touches more file than I prefer. Also, the `.urdf` files are valid urdf files for *parts* of the robot.  Would you approve of a smaller changeset just by adding comments to the top of the urdf files in pull request #462?
content.html: @andy_somerville I like your suggestion, but it touches more file than I prefer. Also, the .urdf files are valid urdf files for parts of the robot. Would you approve of a smaller changeset just by adding comments to the top of the urdf files in pull request #462?
